inlineContent.text: You can use URL objects to construct URLs and access their parts. For URLs that represent local files, you can also manipulate properties of those files directly, such as changing the file’s last modification date. Finally, you can pass URL objects to other APIs to retrieve the contents of those URLs. For example, you can use the
, and
classes to access the contents of remote resources, as described in
URL objects are the preferred way to refer to local files. Most objects that read data from or write data to a file have methods that accept an
object instead of a pathname as the file reference. For example, you can get the contents of a local file URL as an
object using the
initializer, or as an
object using the
initializer.
You can also use URLs for interapplication communication. In macOS, the
class provides the
method to open a location specified by a URL. Similarly, in iOS, the
class provides the
method.
Additionally, you can use URLs when working with pasteboards, as described in NSURL Additions Reference (part of the AppKit framework).
The
class is “toll-free bridged” with its Core Foundation counterpart,
. See
for more information on toll-free bridging.
The Swift overlay to the Foundation framework provides the
structure, which bridges to the
class. For more information about value types, see
in
and
in
An
object is composed of two parts—a potentially
base URL and a string that is resolved relative to the base URL. An
object is considered absolute if its string part is fully resolved without a base; all other URLs are considered relative.
For example, when constructing an
object, you might specify
as the base URL and
as the string part, as follows:
When fully resolved, the absolute URL is
A URL can be also be divided into pieces based on its structure. For example, the URL
contains the following URL components:
Component
Value
The
class provides properties that let you examine each of these components.
For apps linked on or after iOS 17 and aligned OS versions,
parsing has updated from the obsolete RFC 1738/1808 parsing to the same
parsing as
. This unifies the parsing behaviors of the
and
APIs. Now,
automatically percent- and IDNA-encodes invalid characters to help create a valid URL.
To check if a
is strictly valid according to the RFC, use the new
method. This method leaves all characters as they are and returns
if
is explicitly invalid.
For apps linked before iOS 17, the
class parses URLs according to
, and
Starting with OS X v10.6 and iOS 4.0, the
class provides a facility for creating and using bookmark objects. A
bookmark

provides a persistent reference to a file-system resource. When you resolve a bookmark, you obtain a URL to the resource’s current location. A bookmark’s association with a file-system resource (typically a file or folder) usually continues to work if the user moves or renames the resource, or if the user relaunches your app or restarts the system.
For a general introduction to using bookmarks, read
in
In a macOS app that adopts App Sandbox, you can use
security-scoped bookmarks

to gain access to file-system resources outside your app’s sandbox. These bookmarks preserve the user’s intent to give your app access to a resource across app launches. For details on how this works, including information on the entitlements you need in your Xcode project, read
in
. The methods for using security-scoped bookmarks are described in this document in
When you resolve a security-scoped bookmark, you get a security-scoped URL.
Security-scoped URLs provide access to resources outside an app’s sandbox. In macOS, you get access to security-scoped URLs when you resolve a security-scoped bookmark. In iOS, apps that
open
or
move
documents using a
also receive security-scoped URLs.
To gain access to a security-scoped URL, you must call the
method (or its Core Foundation equivalent, the
function). For iOS apps, if you use a
to access the URL, it automatically manages the security-scoped URL for you.
If
(or
) returns
, you must relinquish your access by calling the
method (or its Core Foundation equivalent, the
function). You should relinquish your access as soon as you have finished using the file. After you call these methods, you immediately lose access to the resource in question.

If you fail to relinquish your access when you no longer need a file-system resource, your app leaks kernel resources. If sufficient kernel resources are leaked, your app loses its ability to add file-system locations to its sandbox, using Powerbox, security-scoped bookmarks, or similar APIs, until relaunched.

In a macOS app, when you copy a security-scoped URL, the copy has the security scope of the original. You gain access to the file-system resource (that the URL points to) just as you would with the original URL: by calling the
method (or its Core Foundation equivalent).
If you need a security-scoped URL’s path as a string value (as provided by the
method), such as to provide to an API that requires a string value, obtain the path from the URL as needed. Note, however, that a string-based path obtained from a security-scoped URL
does not
have security scope and you cannot use that string to obtain access to a security-scoped resource.
With OS X v10.10 and iOS 8.0, the NSURL class includes the ability to get and set document thumbnails as a resource property for iCloud documents. You can get a dictionary of
objects in macOS or
objects in iOS using the
or
methods.

code: if let thumbnails = thumbnails as? [NSString: NSImage] {

inlineContent.text: In macOS, you can set a dictionary of thumbnails using the
method. You can also get or set all the thumbnails as an
object with multiple representations by using the
Do not set the
key directly. Modifying this key interferes with document tracking and can create duplicates of your document, as well as other possible problems.
In iOS, use a
subclass to manage your file. Set the thumbnail by overriding the document’s
method and returning a dictionary that contains the proper thumbnail keys (along with any other file attributes).
In macOS, follow the instructions for creating thumbnails given in
Although the thumbnail API is designed to support multiple image resolutions, currently it only supports 1024 x 1024 pixel thumbnails.

abstract.text: An object representing the location of a resource that bridges to
; use
when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An array containing the  path components. (read-only)
The query string, conforming to RFC 1808.
Returns the resource values for the properties identified by specified array of keys.
Sets the URL’s resource properties for a given set of keys to a given set of values.
Initializes and returns bookmark data derived from an alias file pointed to by a specified URL.
A file path URL that points to the same resource as the URL object. (read-only)
Returns whether the URL is a file reference URL.
Creates an alias file on disk at a specified location with specified bookmark data.
Returns a new file reference URL that points to the same resource as the receiver.
A boolean value that determines whether the receiver is a file URL.
The path, conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
Returns the value of the resource property for the specified key.
The URL string for the receiver as an absolute URL. (read-only)
The path extension. (read-only)
The relative path, conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
Initializes a newly created NSURL referencing the local file or directory at
Returns whether the promised item can be reached.
Returns whether the resource pointed to by a file URL can be reached.
Returns a new URL by appending a path component to the original URL.
Removes the cached resource value identified by a given key from the URL object.
Initializes and returns a newly created NSURL object as a file URL with a specified path.
A copy of the URL with any instances of
or
removed from its path. (read-only)
Sets a temporary resource value on the URL object.
Initializes a URL object with a C string representing a local file system path.
A string representation of the relative portion of the URL. (read-only)
A Boolean value that indicates whether the URL string’s path represents a directory.
Returns a new URL object initialized with a C string representing a local file system path.
A URL you create by removing the last path component from the receiver. (read-only)
The password conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
The base URL. (read-only)
A URL you create by removing the path extension from the receiver, if any. (read-only)
The parameter string conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
A C string containing the URL’s file system path. (read-only)
Initializes an NSURL object with a provided URL string.
The scheme. (read-only)
The port, conforming to RFC 1808.
Initializes a newly created NSURL that points to a location specified by resolving bookmark data.
The host, conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
In an app that adopts App Sandbox, revokes access to the resource pointed to by a security-scoped URL.
The fragment identifier, conforming to RFC 1808. (read-only)
Sets the URL’s resource property for a given key to a given value.
Returns a new URL by appending a path component to the original URL, along with a trailing slash if the component is a directory.
Initializes a newly created NSURL with a specified scheme, host, and path.
Initializes and returns a newly created NSURL object as a file URL with specified path components.
Returns the value of the resource property for the specified key.
An absolute URL that refers to the same resource as the receiver. (read-only)
A URL that points to the same resource as the original URL using an absolute path. (read-only)
Initializes and returns a newly created NSURL object as a file URL with a specified path.
Fills the provided buffer with a C string representing a local file system path.
The resource specifier. (read-only)
A URL that points to the same resource as the receiver and includes no symbolic links. (read-only)
Returns a new URL made by resolving the alias file at
In an app that has adopted App Sandbox, makes the resource pointed to by a security-scoped URL available to the app.
Removes all cached resource values and temporary resource values from the URL object.
Returns a new URL by appending a path extension to the original URL.
The last path component. (read-only)
Initializes a newly created NSURL referencing the local file or directory at
Returns the resource values for the properties identified by specified array of keys.
Returns a bookmark for the URL, created with specified options and resource values.
Initializes an NSURL object with a base URL and a relative string.
Returns the resource values for properties identified by a specified array of keys contained in specified bookmark data.
The user name, conforming to RFC 1808.
Reads an NSURL object off of the specified pasteboard.
Writes the URL to the specified pasteboard.
Returns a URL by appending the specified path component with the file extension for a uniform type identifier.
Returns a URL by appending the path extension for a uniform type identifier.
Creates an instance from the provided string, optionally IDNA- and percent-encoding any invalid characters.
Options used when creating bookmark data.
Options used when creating file bookmark data
Options used when resolving bookmark data.
Keys in the userInfo dictionary of an
object when certain NSURL methods return an error.
The schemes that the
class is able to parse.
An alias for this value type's equivalent reference type.
Keys that apply to file system URLs.
